facts.text: Kalyan Singh died sonless in the year 1918 leaving surviving his widow Mst. Bhagwati and two daughters Mst. Indrawati and Mst. Radha Rani.

anchor.surface_text: One Kalyan Singh died sonless in the year 1918 leaving him surviving his widow, Mst. Bhagwati and two daughters., Mst. Indrawati and Mst. Radha Rani.

facts.text: Mst. Bhagwati alienated her husband's estate in favour of certain alienees by a deed dated October 10, 1919.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed, dated October 10, 1919, Mst. Bhagwati alienated her husbands estate in favour of certain alienees.

facts.text: Mst. Indrawati instituted the suit on October 23, 1931 in the Court of the Additional Civil Judge of Mathura in representative capacity on behalf of the reversioners claiming declaration that the alienation was null and void against subsequent heirs of Kalyan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On October 23, 1931, Mst. Indrawati suing in a representative capacity on behalf of the reversioners to the estate of Kalyan Singh, instituted the suit in the Court of the Additional Civil Judge of Mathura, out of which this appeal arises. impleading the alienees as also Mst. Bhagwati and Mst. Radha Rani as defendants and claiming a declaration that the alienation was null and void against the subsequent heirs of Kalyan Singh and that on the death of Mst. Bhagwati, his next heirs would be entitled to get possession of the alienated properties.

facts.text: The trial Judge decreed the suit on August 12, 1941 granting declaration that the alienation is void beyond the lifetime of Mst. Bhagwati and does not bind the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: On Angus 12, 1941, the trial Judge decreed the suit and granted a declaration that the alienation is void beyond the lifetime of Mst Bhagwati and does number bind the reversions, who would be entitled after the death of Mst. Bhagwati to possession over the assets of Babu Kalyan Singh.

facts.text: Some of the alienees preferred an appeal to the Allahabad High Court on February 12, 1942 impleading Mst. Bhagwati, Mst. Indrawati and Mst. Radha Rani as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On February 12, 1942, some of the alienees preferred an appeal to the Allahabad High Court impleading Mst. Bhagwati, Mst. bidrawati and Mst. Radha Rani as respondents to the appeal.

facts.text: Three sons of Mst. Indrawati and two sons of Mst. Radha Rani were impleaded as respondents Nos. 8 to 12 in the High Court appeal but by order dated March 11, 1942 the High Court directed they would not be allowed to be impleaded.

anchor.surface_text: Three sons of Mst. Indrawati and two sons of Mst. Radha Rani were also impleaded as respondent Nos. 8 to 12, but by an order dated March 11, 1942, the High Court directed that those persons would number be allowed to be impleaded as respondents.

facts.text: Mst. Indrawati died during the pendency of the appeal in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal in the High Court, Mst. Indrawati died.

facts.text: By order dated May 11, 1950, the High Court directed Mst. Radha Rani to continue on record in place of deceased Mst. Indrawati as next reversioner.

anchor.surface_text: By an order, dated May 11, 1950, the High Court directed that Mst. Radha Rani would companytinue to be on the record in place of her deceased sister, Mst. Indrawati, and as the next reversioner to the estate of Kalyan Singh.

facts.text: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force on June 17, 1956 during pendency of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal, on June 17, 1956, the Hindu Succession Act. 1956 came into force.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit on September 25, 1957 holding suit not maintainable post Hindu Succession Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted this companytention, allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit. the High Court did number go into the other questions raised in the appeal.

facts.text: Mst. Radha Rani applied to High Court for certificate under Art. 133 on January 2, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1958, Mst. Radha Rani applied to the High Court for grant of a certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate on August 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1958, the High Court granted the certificate,

facts.text: High Court declared the appeal admitted on February 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: and on February 27, 1959, the High Court declared the appeal admitted.

facts.text: Mst. Bhagwati died on May 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On May 29, 1961, Mst. Bhagwati died.

facts.text: High Court despatched records to Supreme Court on or about November 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On or about November 13, 1961, the High Court despatched the records to this Court.

facts.text: No order under O.XVI r.12 of Supreme Court Rules substituting heirs of Mst. Bhagwati was obtained and appeal abated against her.

anchor.surface_text: No order of the High Court under O.XVI, r.12 a  of the Supreme Court Rules substituting the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati in her place was obtained, and the appeal abated against her.

facts.text: Mst. Radha Rani filed petition of appeal in Supreme Court on March 26, 1962 impleading Mst. Bhagwati and sons of Indrawati and Radha Rani as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1962, Mst. Radha Rani filed the petition of appeal in this Court. In this petition of appeal, Mst. Bhagwati and also the above-mentioned three sons of Mst. Indrawati and two sons of Mst. Radha Rani were impleaded as respondents.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 1 to 3 filed Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2219 of 1964 on August 24, 1964 raising preliminary objections.

anchor.surface_text: On August 24, 1964, respondents Nos. 1 to 3 filed Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2219 of 1964 raising certain preliminary objections, and praying that the appeal be dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed names of respondents Nos. 8 to 12 be struck off from the record.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant does number object to this prayer. We direct accordingly that the names of respondents Nos. 8 to 12 be struck off from the record.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment and decree dated September 25, 1957 and directed First Appeal No. 232 of 1942 be heard on merits by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, tile judgment and decree, dated September 25, 1957, of the High Court are set aside, and First Appeal No. 232 of 1942 must number be heard on the merit.-, by the High Court.

facts.text: Mst. Indrawati left three sons impleaded as respondents 10,11,12 and another son Lallu also known as Ram Prasad and two daughters Ram Dulari and Vimla.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the three sons of Mst. Indrawati who are shown as respondents Nos. 10, 11 and 12 in the petition of appeal, Mst. Indrawati left another son, Lallu also known as Ram Prasad and two daughters, Ram Dulari and Vimla.

facts.text: Heirs of Mst. Bhagwati are Mst. Radha Rani and the sons and daughters of Mst. Indrawati.

anchor.surface_text: The heirs of Mst. Bhagwati are Mst. Radba Rani and the sons and daughters of Mst. Indrawati.

precedents.case_name: Gummalapura Taggina Mattada Kotturuswami v. Serta Veeravya
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 14 did not apply to properties in the possession of alienees under an alienation made by the Hindu female before the Act came into force, and in respect of such properties, ss. 14, 15 and 16 of the Act did not abolish the reversioners and reversionary rights

precedents.citation: Brahmadeo Singh and another v. Deomani Missir and others 2

anchor.surface_text: Brahmadeo Singh and another v. Deomani Missir and others 2 . In the last case, the trial Court had decreed a suit by the reversioners for a declaration that two sale deeds executed by a Hindu widow were without legal necessity and number binding upon them. The Patna High Court allowed an appeal by the alienees and dismissed the suit holding that by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable.

Indrawati 4   the decision under appeal in this case  was incorrect, and S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did number extend to property already alienated by a Hindu female. This Court accordingly allowed the appeal, and reversed the decree of the Patna High Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable

anchor.surface_text: Hanuman Prasad v. Indrawati 4   the decision under appeal in this case  was incorrect, and S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did number extend to property already alienated by a Hindu female. This Court accordingly allowed the appeal, and reversed the decree of the Patna High Court. The effect of this decision is that it is open to a reversioner to maintain a suit for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female limited owner before the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act., 1956, was without legal necessity and was number binding upon the reversioners.

precedents.cited_proposition: by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable

precedents.citation: Bijoy Gopal Mukherji v. Krishna Mahishi Debi 1

anchor.surface_text: Bijoy Gopal Mukherji v. Krishna Mahishi Debi 1 . To such a suit by the reversioners for possession of the property after the death of the widow, the heirs of the widow were number necessary parties. precedents.cited_proposition: in the case of an alienation by a Hindu widow, without legal necessity, the reversioners were number bound to institute a declaratory suit during the lifetime of the widow. They companyld wait until her death and then sue the alienee for possession of the alienated property treating the alienation as a nullity without the intervention of any Court. To such a suit ... the heirs of the widow were number necessary parties
